greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of ordered ways to write n = k + m with k > 0 and m > 0 such that phi(k) - 1, phi(k) + 1 and prime(prime(prime(m))) - 2 are all prime, where phi(.) is Euler's totient function.
comment: (ii) Any integer n > 22 can be written as k + m with k > 0 and m > 0 such that prime(k) + 2 and prime(prime(prime(m))) - 2 are both prime.
Note that either part of the conjecture implies the twin prime conjecture.
link: Zhi-Wei Sun, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: a(12) = 1 since 12 = 9 + 3 with phi(9) - 1 = 5, phi(9) + 1 = 7 and prime(prime(prime(3))) - 2 = prime(prime(5)) - 2 = prime(11) - 2 = 29 all prime.
a(103) = 1 since 103 = 73 + 30 with phi(73) - 1 = 71, phi(73) + 1 = 73 and prime(prime(prime(30))) - 2 = prime(prime(113)) - 2 = prime(617) - 2 = 4547 all prime.
results.author: _Zhi-Wei Sun_, Feb 05 2014
